This problem allows the possibility of error in the elements of a given matrix A so that the modified matrix is given by A + E , where E is a correction matrix to be determined. The TLS solution is commonly obtained from the singular value decomposition (SVD) of [AJb] [27] and is able to compute a strongly consistent estimate of the true solution IC when the errors in the data matrix [Alb] are rowwise independently and identically distributed with zero mean and equal variance. If, in addition, the errors are normally distributed, the TLS solution has maximum likelihood properties. However, these nice properties are lost in applications where the matrix A has a special structure since then, the errors are (non)linearly related, and the TLS method does not preserve this special structure. In fact, the matrix E obtained from the SVD will typically be dense, with no structure, even whe,n A is structured or sparse.

For p = 2 and a suitable choice for D , problem (2) is equivalent to the TLS problem (l), with the additional requirement that the matrix E must have the given structure. Algorithms for computing the STLN solution have been developed [20], [2 L]. The STLN method preserves any given affine structure in E or [El-r] and can minimize these corrections in the discrete L, norm, where p = 1. 2 or 00 [2 11. A theoretical justification and computational testing of 1053-587)3/96$05.00 0 1996 IEEE the STLN algorithm confirm that it is an efficient method for solving structured problems or when errors can occur only in some of the elements of A or [AJb] [21]. For instance, when the matrix A has Toeplitz or Hankel structure, the new approach guarantees that E has the same Toeplitz structure as A or that only those elements of E that correct possible noisy elements of il are permitted to be nonzero. For earlier work on problems in which the errors occur in a restricted manner, see [5] and [26l, and for the use of 151 norm in total approximation, see [17 and [30]. The extension of the TLS solution to incorporate the algebraic pattern of the errors in A is also studied in [l] and [6] but both for the La norm only. For a comparison of these two algorithms, see [28]. The approach in our algorithm is different from these two, as will become clear later on.

Cur study of STLN problems (in several norms) is motivated by the numerical and theoretical results reported in marly papers (see e.g., [25] and [27] for an overview), which show that a total least norm fitting ( p = 1, 2, m) does give bettlx results than ordinary least norm fitting (in which only b is corrected) when all data in [AJb] have errors. A strategy for choosing p is not simple, and some discussion on this topi; is included in [25]. In particular, for p = 1, it is well kno m that the solution of the ordinary least 1 -norm problem rnin [(Az -15111 is less sensitive to outliers than the solution witl-other norms. A theoretical analysis in [24] shows that the robustness of least norm fitting and total least norm fitting is similar for p = 1, implying that the TLN solution for p = 1 is also less sensitive to outliers than the TLN solution for other norrns (e.g., p = 2, 00). This robustness of the TLN problem for 11 = 1 compared with that of the TLN problem for p = 2 is also shown for structured problems (i.e., for the STLN problem concidered here) in our preliminary experiments, as reported in a recent paper [18]. This is one important aspect of the STLN formulation, in addition to the fact that it can preserve the problem structure.

This paper extends the study of the STLN problem presented in [20] and [21] in the following way. First of all, we show, in Section IV, how to generalize the STLN problem formulation to structured TLN problems with multiple right-hand side vectxs A X M B and how to compute the corresponding STLN solution. This is an important feature that allows us to solve structure-preserving rank reduction problems for any given rank deficiency. On the other hand, the methods presented in [I] and [6] cannot be directly used for problems with multiple right-hand sides. For clarity of exposition, we brielly describe the STLN algorithms for structured A and [A/hl, as presented in [20] and [21], in Sections I1 and 111. Second, in Section V, convergence properties in model reduction problems are discussed, and finally, in Section VI, the STLN method is applied to various problems in system iden ification and signal processing in which the data matrix is Toeplitz, and the correction matrix E or [El -7-1 preserves the same structure. The presented results also hold for Hankel structures since Hankel matrices simply transform to Toeplitz matrices by permutations. Although STLN has this flexibility of allowing any vector norm, we focus in this paper on its two-norm solutions, mainly because this norm is most often used in signal processing. In addition, this norm gives a fair comparison to the currently used LS and TLS methods in the applications under study.

div.head: VI[. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
div.p: A recently presented new method [20] and [21] related to total least squares (TLS) known as structured total least norm (STLN) for solving overdetermined sets of linear equations Ax N b has been summarized, where A or [Alb] is structured and affected by noise. The main new features of this approach are that it preserves the problem structure and permits the minimization of error in different norms as well, which is important in certain problems to improve robustness of the solution.
The STLN problem is generalized to structured sets converges to the optimal solution in model reduction problems for which the global optimum can be derived analytically.

The benefits of the STLN method in various parameter estimation problems, such as linear prediction, impulse response estimation of multivariable systems, and transfer funclion modeling, are studied. The Lz norm STLN method is compared with the LS and TLS methods and shown to improve the accuracy of the parameter estimates by a factor 2 to 40 at any SNR.

In order to more fully investigate the potential of the STLN problem formulation and algorithms for a range of applications, a number of areas need further study. The benefits of thl-STLN approach and the computational performance of the STLN algorithms need to be investigated in much larger problems arising in actual applications, e.g., in signal enhancement and signal reconstruction and NMR data quantification. The STLN algorithms need further improvements in cases of near rank deficiency of A and ill conditioning of the kernel problem solved in each iteration. In addition, the convergence rate needs further analysis. More refined algorithms with better convergence properties are currently under study [ 151.
